0: ORLANDO -- A man who says he was Orlando shooter Omar Mateen's gay lover is speaking out following the attack on Pulse nightclub that left 49 people dead, and dozens more injured. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In an interview with Univision anchor Maria Elena Salinas, the man -- who was called "Miguel" to protect his identity -- said he first met Mateen on the gay dating app Grindr. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Report: Man claims to have been Omar Mateen's lover NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Univision reported the FBI told the network that investigators have spoken with this man, but a law enforcement official would neither confirm nor deny this to CBS News. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The official told CBS News senior investigative producer Pat Milton that Mateen was a frequent user of online dating sites seeking relationships with both men and women. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Men and women have come forward to the FBI claiming to have had a relationship with Mateen, according to the law enforcement official, and all of those claims are being investigated. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Man who is being called "Miguel" speaks in an interview with Univision about his alleged relationship with Orlando shooter Omar Mateen. His appearance was altered to protect his identity. Univision NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Miguel said in an interview with Univision that Mateen, who was killed by police during the rampage on the Pulse nightclub early on June 12, was gay. He described his relationship with Mateen as "friends with benefits." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said the sexual relationship lasted about two months, and they met at a hotel in Orlando between 15 and 20 times. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Miguel told Univison that he believes Mateen intentionally targeted Latinos in retribution for feeling rejected by Puerto Ricans. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR AG Loretta Lynch: Orlando gunman's motive may never be known NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I believe this is not terrorism," Miguel said, despite investigators saying Mateen called 911 and posted to Facebook to pledge allegiance to ISIS during the rampage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Rather, Miguel claimed Mateen was acting on revenge after being with a Puerto Rican man whom he later learned was HIV positive. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "He hate gay Puerto Ricans for all the stuff he did to him," Miguel said. "I believe this crazy horrible thing he did was for revenge." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Miguel said that Mateen's wife knew he was gay, and that his father forced him into an arranged marriage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Miguel added that he and Mateen also talked about religion. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "He said Muslim religion is beautiful, beautiful religion, where everything is about love," he said. "Everybody is welcome. Gay, trans, bisexual... everybody." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Miguel said that Mateen never appeared to be violent. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "He was looking for love," Miguel said. "He was looking to be embraced." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Investigators have said Mateen "cased" the Pulse nightclub prior to the night of the massacre. There has also been speculation about the gunman's sexuality. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A U.S. official with knowledge of the situation previously told CBS News that club-goers have told investigators that Mateen had been at Pulse numerous times previously. Additionally, other media outlets have heard several stories of Mateen popping up and conversing with men on gay dating apps. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Jim Van Horn, 71, said Mateen was a "regular" at the popular Pulse nightclub. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Van Horn, a retired pharmacist, said he met Mateen once, and the younger man talked about his ex-wife. But Van Horn said his friends soon "told me they didn't want me talking to him, because they thought he was a strange person." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Orlando Sentinel and other news organizations quoted other regulars from Pulse who said they had seen Mateen there a number of times, and many said he was at best strange, at worst a little scary. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Sometimes he would go over in the corner and sit and drink by himself, and other times he would get so drunk he was loud and belligerent," said Ty Smith, who remembered seeing Mateen inside at least a dozen times. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR What we've learned from Orlando shooting documents NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Asked about his son's sexual orientation last week, Seddique Mir Mateen said he did not believe his son was gay. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "To me, that is wrong," Mateen's father told CBS News correspondent David Begnaud. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The elder Mateen said he learned of the speculation from news reports, but as far as he was concerned, "I didn't see any of it and I don't believe that was the case." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While it is still possible Mateen was just very closely surveying his chosen target for terror, former senior FBI profiler Mary Ellen O'Toole told CBS News that doesn't seem likely. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This to me suggests somebody that may have had sexual identity issues
